In one instance, we hear of three who had their backs very much lacerated — a sort of treatment they had not been accustomed to at home — and so they ran off a second time: but on this occasion from the Yankees-- Fred. Herald.
The Louisville Journal says: It would be no wonder if the spirit of rebellion were to burn fiercely in our city, considering how many petticoats it is fanned with.
The Catholic clergy of New Orleans have sent word to Gen. Beauregard that the bells of every Catholic Church in New Orleans are at his disposal, to be re-cast into cannon.
The Presbyterian congregation of Staunton, Va, have donated their bell, weighing about 400 pounds, to the Government, in response to Gen. Beauregard's request.
Wm. Quesenberry, for many years a citizen of Fredericksburg, Va, died on the 14th of March.
Brigadier General S. G. French has been assigned to the command of the district of Cape Fear, N. C.
The ladies of Lynchburg, Va., are organizing a Gun boat Association.
Captain R. Dindsay Walker has been promoted to the rank of Major of Artillery.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 74, page 3.

div3.head: The fight at the Valley.
div3.p:
We have received some few additional particulars of the fight near Winchester on Sunday last.
As stated in our issue of yesterday, our force in the engagement scarcely exceeded 3,500 One regiment was held as a reserve and from 1,500 to 1,600 of our troops failed to arrive in time to participate in the engagement.

We append a list of the wounded in company of this city, which has been furnished as by a gentleman who left Woodstock on Tuesday night. Sergeant Tucker Randolph, Privates Grey, Picot, Annually, Genty of Renwig, Danforth, C. Taylor, and E. Taylor.
Most of these were only slightly wounded.
There were none of the members of the corp killed.

Among the killed and wounded in the 23d regiment, we have the following names: Lieut. E. Crump, of company H,(Richmond Sharp Shooters.) wounded, but not severely.
Lieut. C. is from this city, and was an occasional correspondent for this paper, over the signature of "Ned."
H. L. Francisco, company G, killed. He was from Louisa county.
Serg't Vanabic company I, killed . From Prince Edward county.

Capt J. T. Walton, company H, wounded at the sit from Charlotte county.
Privates John G Pettus, of same company, killed and P G. Elbank mortally wounded.--John B Privates wounded and missing.

Leute at Curtle of company F.
slightly wounded.

Second Lieut. Jack Heth, of the Irish battalion was killed in the action.
If we are not fighter.
Lieu' Heth was a Stanton of Prince Poyden, formerly proprietor of the Estrange Hotel.
In this city, and is remembered by many of our citizens.

Agreement who was engaged in the fight arrived at the city yesterday evening, and from we obtain some fuller particulars.
On Saturday morning a brush fight took place between the commands of Col. Ashby and Chas's Artillery, and the advance guard of the agency's forces.
It is alleged that it was in this fight that Gen Shields was wounded.
He was wounded in the arm, which was amputated after his return to Winchester.
Gen. Banks had his horse shot under him.

After the fight on Sunday the enemy retired to Winchester, and information from citizens who came out the next day states that they were engaged all night in bringing in their killed and wounded, which they admit to be not less than 1,500.
Some even put it as high as 3,000.
General Jackson in person headed five different charges, each time driving the enemy back upon his reserves.

In one of the gallant charges made, a portion of Col. Fulnerson's regiment was surrounded and made prisoners.
The loss of this regiment is about 150, a number of whom as doubt are in the hands of the enemy as prisoners.

div3.head: Col. John Echols.
div3.p:
We are greatly pained to learn that Col. John Echols was so seriously wounded in the arm in the late battle near Winchester, that it is feared amputation may be necessary.-- A more gallant and noble gentleman does not live.
His gentle and engaging manner, and genuine modesty of character, have made him hosts of friends, who have observed his military career and splendid courage with profound admiration, and who feel deep go solitude for his welfare.
P. S.--Since writing the above, we have been gratified to learn that the wound of Col. Echols is not considered dangerous, and is much more slight than was at first supposed.

div3.head: A gallant regiment.
div3.p:
There are few more efficient regiments in the Confederate service than the 3d Virginia regiment commanded by Roger A. Pryor.--We are glad to learn that of the entire command, (900 strong,) only sixty-eight decline to re-enlist.
The rest have been actually mustered into service for the war. The sixty-eight who decline to re-enlist embrace many who are diseased, some who are over 45, and others whom circumstances oblige to return home for a session.
If every regiment in the service does as well as the 3d, Virginia will promptly furnish her contingent to the good cause.

div3.head: Arrival of Lieut. Minor.
div3.p: We learn that Lieutenant Minor, who was wounded in the naval battle at Hampton Roads, arrived here last Monday evening. We are pleased to learn that he is rapidly recovering from his wound, and in a fair way to engage soon again in that service upon which he has reflected such marked distinction and honor.

It appears that Lieut. M. received his wound when on his way in an open boat, with a gallant crew, to burn the "Congress"--a duty which he was restrained from performing by his recall to the Merrimac.
The fire from the enemy's musketry on the shore was so destructive as to render the advance of the boat impossible.
Before she was ordered to return, Lieut. Misor and two of the boat's crew were wounded, one of the latter having his eye knocked out by a Minnie ball.

Those associated with Lieut. Minor in that terrible conflict, speak of his conduct in terms of extravagant praise.
He displayed a coolness and a courage worthy the greatest hero of any age. The heroism which he displayed in volunteering to go and destroy the Congress, to stimulated the gallant crew of the Merrimac as to have caused them to rush en passe to the boat to accompany him in his during exploit, when a volunteer crew was called for.

Such gallantry surely deserves some especial mark of appreciation, and we would fain hope, for the honor of the Government, no less than as a motive for similar deeds of gallantry by others in the future, that some substantial token of appreciation commensurate with the achievements of that gallant officer will be given forts with.

div3.head: $7 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, about two weeks ago, a light, gingerbread-colored boy, named Robert; very dirty in his appearance.
He was hired from Thomas J. Bagley, Agent, on Wall street, 1st January last.
I have no doubt he is lurking or employed at some of the soldier camps or hospitals.
His owner lives in Norfolk, Va. I will give the above reward of seven dollars to any. be who will deliver him to me or secure him in jail, so I get him again.
div3.closer:
E. J. Crump,
Corner Leigh and 2d sts.
Richmond. Va. mt 28--2at*

div3.head: $25 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my store, on Tuesday morning, 15th instant, my Negro Boy, Lewis Washington.
He is a bright mulatto, thick set, about 5 feet high, 15 years old; had on when last seen a brown sack coat, brown pants, and a military cap. The above reward will be paid for his delivery to me.
div3.closer:
S.S. Cottrell.
No. 129 Main st. mh 28--3t*

div3.head: Married,
div3.p: On the 28th, by Rev. W. W. Bennett, Mr. John W. Hurbard, of Baltimore, to Miss Martha Virginia Renney, of Mississippi.
Norfolk navere please copy.

div4.p: On Thursday morning, the 27th inst, at the residence of C L. McCoull, in Henrico county, Olivere, only child of John and Kate Hammond, of Baltimore, Md.

The funeral will take place from Leigh Street Baptist Church this (Friday) morning, at 10 o'clock. The friends and acquaintances of the family, and those of C. L. McCoull, are respectfully invited to attend.
In this city, on the 27th inst., after a brief illness, in the 14th year of her age, Jose Phine, daughter of Mrs. H. H. Dalton.
The funeral will take place from St. James Church, this afternoon, at 3½ o'clock. The relatives and friends of the family are invited to attend without further notice.
In this city, on Monday, the 24th instant, Downer Page, eldest child of Capt. C. K. Sherman, late of Washington, D. C., aged six years and eight months.

The funeral will take place from St. James Church at 12 M. to-day.
The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend.

At 3 o'clock, on the morning of Thursday the 20th inst., at the residence of Captain C. C. Tinsley in the county of Hanover, after a Gingering Illness.
John Winston Reeve, formerly of this city, aged 32 years.

In South Carolina, on the 7th of March, in the blissful hope of a glorious resurrection, Chas. Edwin Anderson, son of Rev Albert and Mrs. Louisa A. Anderson, aged 24 years, leaving a wife and two infant children.
He was a member of Capt. Leak's artillery company, of Goochland county, and was accidentally shot in the knee on the 29th of December; from which he suffered excruciating pain for five or six weeks before he fell asleep in Jesus.

lg.l: Asleep in Jesus; oh; how sweet,
To be for such a slumber meet;
That death hath lost its venomed sting.
No fear, no we, shall dim that hour,

div3.head: Wanted — laborers
div3.p:
--The Legislature having made an appropriation to enable the James River and Kanawha Company to keep open the navigation of the canal, and to improve the navigation of James and Jackson's rivers, from Buchanan to Covington, a number of laborers are required for those purposes.
Persons having slaves to hire for the residue of this year, or for a shorter period, will please address the undersigned, at the office of the company, Richmond, Va.
div3.closer:
Wm P. Munford Secretary
Of the Jas. River and Kanawha Co. mh 28--eod1w

div3.head:
Wanted--
Fifteen Recruits.
div3.p:
Fifteen recruits will be received this day in the Dickinson Light Artillery now stationed at Camp Lee, to complete its quota.
Substitutes will be received.
Apply at the Office, on 10th street, between Main and Cary.

Our Company of Flying Artillery being nearly completed, those who wish to enter Major B Ggs's Battalion are invited to join at once.
Twelve experienced Drivers can secure a good place by applying early at the Recruiting Office of the Battalion, Bank street, two doors from 12th.

div3.head: Military notice.
div3.p: Having been authorized by the War Department to raise, enlist, and muster into service, a Battalion of Infantry, for the war, to be composed of volunteers not now in the service, I am desirous of the co-operation and assistance of others.
Those wishing to join me in this patriotic undertaking, will please see me in this city, or address me in writing corner of Leigh and 6th streets.

div3.head:
Hdq'rs Recruiting Station,
4th La. Vols, 109 Main street.
Richmond, Va., March 27, 1862.
div3.p: all men Recruited by Lieut. M B. Teavis are hereby notified to report themselves at this office, at 12 o'clock M., on the 28th inst. Those not reporting on or before 12 o'clock M., on the 29th inst, will be considered and treated as deserters.
div3.closer:
Chas. Murray, Ord'y Serg't.
Per order Lieut. M. B. Travis. mh 28--3t*

div3.head: Deserter--$25 reward.
div3.p: The above reward will be paid for Alexander L Cox; 27 years of age; 5 feet inches high; fair complexion; hazel eyes; brown hair; lately a resident of Richmond; born in Rockingham county, Va. Be deserted on his way to the regiment, at Culpeper C. H., and is believed to be now in this city.
div3.closer:
Lieut, John J. Lutts,
Recruiting Officer, Co. E, 1st. Md. Reg.
Office cor. 9th and Main sts. mh 28--3t*

div3.head:
Attention!
young men.
div3.p:
All persons in the city of Richmond, and within one mile of the corporate limits north of James river, who are between the ages of 16 and 18 years, are summoned to attend at the City Hall, this (Friday) afternoon, at 4 o'clock, to elect company officers for the military of the second class.
Appointments for meetings at other places are recalled, and all will assemble at the City Hall.
div3.closer:
H. K. Ellyson, Sheriff of
City of Richmond. mh 28--1t*

div3.head: Attention, Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--I am authorized by the Governor to receive Substitutes in my company of Light Artillery, and to muster them in as they come.
Those, therefore, who desire to procure substitutes, or who wish to become substitutes, should call at once at my headquarters, Johnson &Guigon's office, under the Whig Building.

div3.head: Curl's heavy Artillery.
div3.p:
--A few more Recruits are waited to fill up the ranks of the above company to one hundred men. The company is now stationed at Jamestown, and is attached to Mal, Wm Allen's Battalion of Heavy Artillery.
The usual bounty of $50 will be paid, and clothing furnished.
For information, apply at M. Jones's, on Cary street, or address either one of the undersigned at Jamestown.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --All those who have enlisted in the Magruder Light Artillery, who do not immediately report themselves at the Recruiting Office, No. 7 Wall street, or at Camp, in Yorktown, will be considered deserters, and treated as such.

Men wishing to join the
Otey Battery
will report immediately to the Captain at Camp Lee, (New Fair Grounds.) The company is now under orders and will leave in a few days for the seat of war.

div3.head:
Hdq'rs Crutchfield light Artillery,
March 13th, 1862.
attention, volunteers!
Battery secured.
div3.p:
The undersigned, having secured a splendid Battery of field-pieces, have authority to raise a company of Light Artillery, to be mustered in the Provisional Army of Virginia for the war, and have received authority from the Governor to recruit volunteers from the Militia, to fill the ranks of the Crutchfield Light Artillery.
The company will be mustered in as soon as a sufficient number of volunteers have been received.
A fine opportunity now presents itself in those who do not wish to go as militiamen, to enroll themselves as volunteers.
No substitutes received.
Apply at the office of the Old Dominion Insurance Company, under the St. Charles Hotel.

div3.head:
Attention, volunteers!
of Goochland,
div3.p:
Cumberland, Louisa, Powhatan, and Buckingham counties, Richmond city, and others — The undersigned, being specially authorized by the Secretary of War to recruit men for the reorganization, for the war, of the old and tried company H, 46th-regiment Virginia volunteers, Wise Legion, commanded by Captain Randolph Harrison, of Goochland county, purposes to receive immediately fifty volunteers.
Only able-bodied men need apply.
Apply soon to
div3.closer:
Lieut. Peyton Wise.
Recruiting Officer and A. A. Q. M.,
At Belvin's Building, No. 2, 20 floor;
or at Camp Wise, near the Reservoir. mh 26--6t*

div3.p: --I am authorized by the Governor of Virginia to raise a Company of Light Artillery for the war, All those desirous of enlisting in this the most effective arm of the service, would do well to call at once at the office of Johnson &Guigon, Whig Building.
Uniforms and subsistence furnished.

div3.head:
War Department,
Adjutant and Inspect on Gen.'s Office.
Richmond, March 24, 1862.
div3.p:
General Orders, No. 16--All leaves of absence and furlongs, from whatever source obtained, are revoked; and officers and men absent from duty, except on surgeon's certificate of disability, will return at once to their respective commands.
It is with extreme reluctance that the Department adopts a measure which deprives our patriotic soldiers of the relaxation they have so well earned; but the enemy presses on every side, and the necessities of the service demand new illustrations of that noble self-denial which has been so many times evinced since the commencement of our struggle for independence.
The furloughs of all who have engaged for the war, which are thus curtailed, will be extended hereafter, when circumstances permit.
But, judging from the past, no fears are entertained of an unwilling response to this call.
Those who have so many times proved their devotion to their country, cannot be indifferent or backward in this hour of her greatest need.
div3.closer:
By order of the President.
S. Cooper,
Adjutant and Inspector Gen. mh 27--6t

div3.head:
Adj't &Insp. General's Office.
Richmond, March 26th, 1862.
special Orders no. 69.
[extract]
div3.p:
VII.
The Military Department of Henrico, under the command of Brigadier-General J. H. Winder, is extended to include the city of Petersburg, and the a joining and surrounding country to the distance of
div3.closer:
By command of the secretary of War.
John Withers,
Ass't Adj't General. mh 27--6t

div3.head:
Attention--
Stevens's heavy Artillery.
div3.p: This Company, named in honor of our worthy Vice-President, the soldier's friend and organized by special authority of the Secretary of War, needs thirty more men to complete its complement.
Militia men, you have the privilege to volunteer in this company, and it may be your last chance, as no other authority to raise companies will be issued until Virginia has furnished her quota.

$50 bounty and uniforms furnished.
Call at the Recruiting Office, corner 15th and Main streets, Nott's stand.

I am receiving and mastering Substitutes in daily.
They can be mustered in hourly.
Call at my office, opposite the Law Building, Franklin street.

div3.head: Flying Artillery.--
div3.p: We are authorized to raise a company of Flying Artillery, to be composed of young men between the ages of sixteen and eighteen, and to be attached to Major Archer's Tredegar (Eighth) Battalion Virginia Volunteers.
The guns we propose to use can be seen at the Tredegar Works.
Each member will be expected to provide himself with a cheap uniform
div3.closer:
J. F. Goodwin,
Jno. E. Tanner.
Tredegar Iron Works,
Richmond, Mar. 24, 1862. mh 25--ts

div3.head: The Manchester Artillery.
div3.p:
I will be n Manchester until Monday, 31st inst., for the purpose of obtaining Recruits for this Company, stationed at present at Sewell's Point Battery, Norfolk harbor.
All desirous of joining a good company, which has seen service, can communicate with me at my store in Manchester.
Recruits will be entitled to the usual bounty of $50 and pay for clothing.
div3.closer:
Emmet W. Weisiger,
Comd'g Manchester Artillery. mh 25--5t*

div3.head:
Adju't &Insp. General's Office,
Richmond.
March 20th, 1862.
special Orders no. 64.
[extract]
div3.p:
"VIII.
Any proceedings taken by the authorities of the State of Virginia for the collection of the public revenue, are hereby exempted from the operation of General Others, No. 9, 11, and 13, A &I. G. O. of March 1st, 8th, and 14th, declaring martial law."
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
John Withers,
Assistant Adjutant-General. mh 21--6t

div3.head: Battalion of Cavalry
div3.p:
--In the month of February I received authority from the Secretary of War to raise a battalion or regiment of Cavalry.
I have hesitated to undertake to do so until this time and I now propose to raise a Battalion of Cavalry, if it can be done without absenting myself too much from my present command.

Penous desiring to unite with me in this patriotic effort, and those wishing authority to recruit and raise companies, will address me at this place; or what is still better, report in person at once.
I expect to have two companies of infantry and one of artillery attached to my command.

Call for the present at Messrs. Yarborough's south side of Main street, three duos above 7th.
or at my company quarter.
New Fair Grounds.

closer.signed: Capt. Comd'g Cavalry Co., P A. C. S.

div3.head:
Howitzer and Rifle
Light Battery.
div3.p:
By authority of the Secretary of War, my company will be transferred to the
Light Artillery service,
and I have secured a splendid Battery of
Howitzers,
and wrought iron bre ch loading
Rifle guns,
of the most approved patents.
This is the most effective, popular, and distinguished arm of the service.

The Battery will be fully
Mounted and
Equipped.

A Bounty of
fifty dollars
allowed to each recruit, and
thirty dollars
by the city of Petersburg.
Apply at once.
div3.closer:
Jas. R. Branch.
Capt. C. K. 16th Reg't Va. Vols.,
Craney Island, near Norfolk, Va.
I shall remain in Petersburg a few days to receive recruits
J. R. B. [mh 23--12t]

div3.head:
State Armory, corner 7th and Cary sts.,
Richmond, March 21, 1862.
div3.p: Arms.--Parties sending arms from the country to this Department are requested to put a memorandum in each box, stating contents and the name of the sender.

div3.head:
Heavy Artillery.
$50 bounty, and
Uniforms furnished.
div3.p:
The undersigned are authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Company for the heavy Artillery service.
We have been for the past eleven months in active service as Lieutenants of such a company, and have already a number of men enlisted.
All who desire to join us will please apply at our recruiting office, No. 17, Main street, upstairs, to Wm. Lawson, Company H, First Regiment Virginia Volunteers; or at our Camp in Yorktown.

div3.head:
Headq'rs Dep't of Henrico,
Richmond, Va.,March 21, 1862.
General Orders, no. 11.--
div3.p: I. Agencies for the obtaining of substitutes are forbidden under such penalties as may be imposed by a court martial; When such agencies are employed, both the principal and the substitute will be impressed into the military service, and the money paid for the substitute will be confiscated by the Government. * * * * *
div3.closer:
By order of
John H. Winder,
Brigadier General Commanding, &c.
L. R. Page,
S. A. General. mh 22--1w

div3.head:
Heavy Artillery.--
attention,
Substitutes.
div3.p:
By authority of the Governor of Virginia to raise a Company of Heavy Artillery, (to be part of Virginia's quota,) I will receive twenty substitutes this day; if of irreproachable character.
None others head apply.--Office at the corner of Franklin and 12th sts.

div3.head:
African Church.
Thursday and Friday evening.
27th and 28th inst.
div3.p:
Tom, the Blind negro Boy Pianist,
The Inspired Musician.
The Wonder of the World.
The Greatest Marvel on Earth.
A Living Miracle.
You must see and hear to believe
Tom will perform his soul-stirring and thrilling composition.
the Settle of Manassas

div3.head: Administrate.X's Sale of real estate,&c., in Chesterfield county.
div3.p:
--Will be sold on the premises, on Thursday, the 17th day of April next, (if fair; if not, the next fair day,) a tract of Land called "Chesnut Grove," near Clover Hull Pits, on the Summit, containing 110 acres, one half cleared, well enclosed, and in a high state of cultivation balance in wood of growth.
On this form is a comfortable dwelling-house with four rooms, and all necessary out-buildings, such as barn, dairy, stables, smoke-house, bath-house, &c. All the buildings are new.
On the same day will be sold all the perishable property on said estate, consisting of Horses, Cows, Sheep, one Carriage one Buggy, Household and Kitchen Furniture.
At the same time will be hired out for the balance of the year, three Negroes--two women and one man.

Terms of Sale--For the land, one-third cash; balance at 6 and 12 months, purchaser giving negotiable notes, interest added, title retained until last note is paid.
For all other property, cash on delivery

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 74, page 4.

argument.p: the enemy's operations on the coast--the people Aroused — skirmishes — port Pulaski, &c., &c.,

div4.head: [special correspondence of the Dispatch]
div4.p:
Dupont, in his report to the Secretary of the Navy at Washington, speaking of the capture of Pernandina and the evacuation of the posts on St. Simon's Sound, says that the coast of Georgia is now entirely in his hands, or under his control, and quoting from his instructions, emanating without doubt from from the wise Gideon Welles himself, adds that the whole State of Georgia is thus laid open to his force and reduced to his power.
The fruits of his brilliant victories will prove but dust and ashes, however, when his supporters shall make the attempt to avail themselves of their vaunted successes, and will find out to their cost that Mr. Gideon Welles has not learned his lesson apply when he quotes a maxim of military science utterly inapplicable to the present content.

What advantage he foresees from the occupation of a line of coast sparsely populated, yielding Ettlato the material progress of this war, unvisited by a commercial flag, it is difficult to discern.
Even the little of value which the islands produced, and which Yankee cupidity coveted, has long since been removed or destroyed.
At Brunswick he found nothing to repay his labor, and at Darian, which had become the depot of an immense lumber trade with Europe, the naval stores have been burned and the lumber sent adrift.
The conquest will be found, by our people at least, of no importance, and affecting in an inappreciable degree the cause we are now engaged in.

It is a matter of regret, and a source of humiliation, however, that he has been allowed with justice to disparage the courage and fortitude of our soldiers.
The strong fortifications which had been there erected with much labor and expense, by his acknowledgment, could have maintained a formidable resistance to the advance of his vessels — most of which, by his report, were gunboats carrying but few guns and unable to stand the fire of a well served battery.
There have been many blunders throughout this war, and this affair has to be added to the list of our unfortunate casualties.
To whom the dishonor will attach, is impossible, with our information, now to decide; but the Government that suspended Floyd and Pillow should not hesitate to examine into the matter.
The headquarters of the Department of East Florida was established at Tallahassee, and therefore, far from the very coast, exposed to the assaults of an active and formidable enemy, within easy striking distance, the General commanding passed the dull intervals between his evening enjoyments.
What was the object of making the town of Tallahassee the centre of a command which should have been constantly on the alert along the Atlantic coast, it is not easy to make out, and cannot be made clear to ordinary intelligence.

Our people are now beginning to feel that we are in the midst of a desperate war. The enthusiasm which has taken hold of the country springs from adversity, and the urgent need which demands from every gallant heart his exertion to save our liberties.
It comes from a more healthy and durable impulse than the wild, irregular, and spasmodic fervor which the battle of Fort Sumter created, and which Manassas finally quenched by the pride it engendered.

We have been quiet in our neighborhood for some days, although little skirmishes occasionally take place when a Federal boat's crew feature to approach too near our lines.
Some days since an armed barge was ambushed and most gallantly attacked at Proctor, on Goose Creek, in South Carolina.
The enemy beat a hasty retreat, after suffering from a well sustained fire.
Again, at Mackay's Point, our pickets gave them a warm reception, at close quarters, and they were compelled to retire without obtaining a flat which they attempted to secure, and with some loss of life, too, judging from the groans which came from the boat.

We have still to chronicle the return of the venerable sarkis.
Washington, from Fort Pulaski, bringing with him letters from the garrison.
They represent the command in excellent spirits and health, and complaining of little save the separation from their friends.
Their commissary is well supplied with the necessaries of garrison life, with the exception of coffee, and with the universally rainy season we have had Abey cannot complain of any scarcity of water, which is the greatest source of anxiety for the fort.
Our summer will, it is generally feared, be a long and dry one judging from the average experience of a number of years, and we fear the fever may be added to the misfortunes of our most unhealthy season.
Our Yankee friends, however, will most assuredly have the full benefit, if not in the form of yellow jack, at least in that almost equally to be dreaded malarious disease known as the country fever, and which, even with incautious persons, however much acclimated, results generally fatally.
We can wish them no worse fortune than an early visit from that pestilent invader.

Throughout the South attention has been directed generally to the question of the coming crop, and thanks to the efforts of the press, persistently exerted, a beneficial result has, I think; been attained.
It is a work of much trouble and expense, ordinarily, to change the system of culture which has been adopted after long experience; and until lately, I believe, the planters of the South were reluctant to abandon the cotton crop.--The fall of Donelson and the loss of the great avenue through which the greatest portion of our grain was received, has forced them, however, to take into earnest consideration the question of our support and that of the army, which must be maintained from the resources of the Cotton States almost wholly.
It is patent to every one that the usual crop of cotton being planted, would take a vast ares away from the grain culture, which, instead of remaining the same as in previous years, should be largely increased, not only to make up the great waste and contingencies of war, but to cover the large tracts takes away from the support of the Confederacy and others abandoned by their laborers.--This, as long as it was left merely to the patriotism of the planters, unsupported and enforced by the press, would have resulted in no commensurate good, in as much as many would have planted as much more as his neighbor has failed to sow, and the area being frequently subscribed, a more careful system of culture would have resulted in a crop fully equal to that of average years.
But the absolute necessity, I think, from observation, has been made so apparent, that the cereal crop will be fully up to the required demand.
Still, the upper portion of Georgia and that portion of Tennessee not invaded, and the whole of Virginia, should devote itself to produce a crop of wheat which will equal the demand of the entire South.
The greater portion of the Confederacy being unfit for the cultivation of wheat, the farmers of those sections will find themselves more than repaid by the profits resulting from their coming crop.
Mercury.

argument.p: the blockade in Parliament — letter from Mr. Mason, &c., &c.

div4.p:
By a late arrival we have extracts from English papers, concerning affairs on this continent.
They will be found interesting, since they furnish some portion of the history of the war:

div4.head: Letter from Mr. Mason.
div4.p: The following letter of the Confederate Envoy, Mason, is among the blockade papers submitted to Parliament:

div5.p:
--I have the honor to transmit to your lordship herewith (by permission) returns of vessels entered and cleared at the blockaded ports of the Confederate States of America, at the respective dates to which they refer.
Your lordship will observe that the returns from the port of Charleston and Savannah are only up to the 31st of October last; from New Orleans, Mobile, Pensacola, and Lavaca, to the dates given in August; and from Wilmington till 10th September.--Your lordship will further observe that in the list from New Orleans a large number were inland by the river Mississippi and therefore involved no question of a breach of blockade.
Wishing to be perfectly frank, it may be proper to remark, also, that others from some of the ports may have been inland; that is to say, through the and sounds along the coast.

"I state, as an example, from New Orleans to Mobile, where the route for small vessels may or may not have been through the inland sounds.
But in regard to the latter, I do not see why the obligations of a blockade do not extend as fully to them as by access to the port from the open sea. These estuaries or sounds are accessible by inlets from the sea, and, if not guarded, the ports to which they lead may be reached as successfully by sea, going vessels of light drought through those channels as by a direct sea routs.
That the Government of the United States so considered is proved by the fact that the inland set communication between New Orleans and North Charleston and Savannah, and, perhaps, other places is dislike to be blockaded by naval forces of that Government.

"The transcript herewith were those furnished to me by my Government, to be communicated to your lordship.
Although purporting to be copies of the original returns, they were copies made at the proper department at Richmond from those returns, and are, therefore, authentic, I ask permission also to include herewith a printed list of vessels entered and cleared at ports in Cuba from and to the blockaded ports of the Confederate States.
These, for the most part, are enumerated in September, and all for the months of November and December are, of course not included in the transcripts from my Government.
This paper, sent to me from Havana, was taken from official documents there by a gentleman of intelligence and integrity, well-known to me, and worthy of entire reliance.
The marginal notes are, of course, unofficial.

"The fact (assumed) of the arrival of the vessels cleared (at their ports of destination) was matter of notoriety, from the almost daily intercourse between Havana and those ports.
I have no official returns from my Government for the months of November, December and January, to be accounted for in the fact that, until very recently, it could not be known when I might reach London.
But, as your Lordship is doubtless aware, breaches of the blockade at most, if not all of these ports, by vessels of large as well as small tonnage, both inward and outward bound, have been during the last three months, and yet are constantly reported.

div4.p:
The following dispatch from Lord Lyons to Karl Russell, respecting the obstruction of the Southern harbors, has just been laid before Parliament.
It was received on the 24th of February:

div5.p: Yesterday, in obedience to the instruction conveyed to me by your lordship's dispatch of the 10th ultima, I spoke to Mr. Seward respecting the obstruction of Southern harbors by vessels sunk at the entrance by order of the United States Government.

"I referred to the conversation which I had held with him on the same subject on the 11th of last month, and I observed to him in your lordship's words, "that the object of war is peace, and the purposes of peace are mutual good will and advantageous intercourse, but that this proceeding will deprive war of its legitimate object, by stripping peace of its natural fruits."

"After some further conversation, Mr. Seward told me that I might inform your lordship that all the vessels laden with stone, which had been prepared for obstructing the harbors, have been already sunk, and that it is not likely that any others will be used for that purpose.

div4.head: The London times on intervention.
div4.p: The London Times, of March 1st, in an article on East Russell's letter to Lord Lyons, says:

q.p:
These statements, which we have abridged from Lord Russell's dispatch, seem to us to embody the doctrines of truth and moderation, and, though treating of war and repression, are evidently founded on the Christian Maxim that we should do to others as we would have them do to us. Were we engaged in blockading an enemy's coast, we could desire no fairer or more equitable rule to be laid down for the guidance of neutrals than that which we are prescribing for ourselves.
To look rather to the sincerity and good faith of the undertaking than to accidental faults in its performance, to forbear from specious excuses in order to justify us in doing that, under the pretence of a respect for public w which we are urged to do by a shortsighted view of our own interest, is worthy of a great people powerful enough to disregard the arts of chicane, and rich enough to bear without flinching a severe check to its commercial and manufacturing industry.

div4.p:
But such advice is not only just, it is also eminently wise.
We are the last people who should do anything to invalidate the right of blockade, for we know not when we may be compelled to resort to it, or how soon a hasty policy might recoil upon ourselves.
England is too great to be often neutral, and should not forget that the arguments she might now employ against her neighbor might, we know not how soon, be retorted against herself with all the force of admissions.
It is not well to encourage doctrines which lead people to acts of violence or fraud in order to build upon them a claim of right and of justice.

If we pass from these general considerations, no policy can be clearer than that of leaving North and South to settle their difference without our interference.
Whatever interested writers or speakers may assert to the contrary, nothing can be more sure than that we have hitherto observed the most absolute neutrality between the North and the South.
Let us persevere to the end, and not give either party the opportunity of saying that the struggle which tore the American continent in two was produced or terminated by our selfish or interested intervention.--There are symptoms that the civil war cannot very long be protracted.
Let its last embers burn down to the last spark without being trodden out by our feet.

div4.head: A French Candidate for the Mexican throne.
div4.p:
The claims of the Archduke Maximilian to the throne of Montezuma are, it appears, contested by no less a candidate than a certain M. Bertron, who resides in the department of the Seine, and lives by extracting oil from Paris dirt.
He has issued the following election address:

Mexicans: For a long period I was humanitary candidate for a place in the Corps Legislatif.
My fellow-citizens were, thank God, always deaf to my exhortations, for a higher destiny was in store for me — the destiny of being charged with working for the welfare of Mexico.
I have been told that you absolutely desire a King.
If you do, take me. I am not of royal race.
I am only a proprietary at Seenaux, in the department of the Seine, and extract oil from the filth of Paris.
I would, were you to honor me with your confidence reduce to order the chaos of Mexican anarchy.
I would dismiss the great army that has not known how to protect the high ways or abstain from plundering what it should guard, and all the money which the soldiers devoured I would expend on works of public utility.
They would, under my government, become householders and take care of their own daughters, instead of abducting those of other men, and keeping alive that passion for gambling, so fatal to your country, your dignity, and your liberty.
In the interior I would suffer each to have his own way in his own concerns.
You would thus become accustomed to dispense with much of a Government, and learn how to take care of yourselves and protect your own interests.
As for me, I would be satisfied with the most civil list that is possible, being desirous of giving you the example of simplicity.

div3.head:
From Nashville.
a Federal view of Affairs.
div3.p: A late number of the Chicago (Illinois) Times contains the subjoined letter from its special correspondent:

Nashville, Tenn., March 7.--The route to Louisville was yesterday thrown open to the public, and all are now free to come and go as they choose without the restriction and hindrance of passports.
The railroad is in running operation, without one obstruction, the bridge at Bowling Green, which was too large a structure to be immediately rebuilt.
All the other bridges have been rebuilt, and the obstructions have been removed.
The efforts of the retreating army to disable the road amounting to little or nothing, although many boasts were made in regard to the completeness of the road.
In a week afterwards the Federal army passed over it and entered Nashville, much to their surprise and chagrin.
They have pursued the same course in their retreat south of here, and doubtless with the same results.
When our army gets ready to advance, it will go forward as fast as though the road was straight and clear.

While communication is thus freely established with the North, the means of going South are not less readily obtained.
All that is require is that the persons who propose to travel should take the oath of allegiance, when they are furnished with a pass to go anywhere they choose.
This implies that General Buell is not much afraid of spies.
In fact, the most effectual method of confounding the Rebels is by giving them correct information of the number of our army, its arms, resources, and discipline.
With such information in their possession, they will not presume to oppose their meagre forces to it. In connection with the facilities extended northward, I must not forget to mention the opening of Adams's Express.
This enterprising establishment sends off its first message to-day, and henceforward people in the United States will be loss in the transmission of matter to this locality.
To the press, it is an invaluable auxiliary on account of the regularity and dispatch which is secured in the transmission of correspondence.

General Grant has made the preliminary steps to wards another movement, and we anticipate a combined action on the part of Gen. Buell.
The vast army now collecting here will require some days, and perhaps weeks, to prepare for a march.
Provisions are to be provided, routes are to be assorted, and bridges are to be rebuilt.
From all that can be gathered the rebels are making a stand in the North of Alabama, which is accessible both by railroad from this point, and by river from General Grant's position.
Their numbers are not above 20,000, except as they are reinforced by volunteers, who will at best constitute a mob, against whom our trained forces will contend with manifest advantage.
They have spread ruin in their pathway wherever they have gone.
Bridges, boats, railroad struck, and whatever else can subserve the use of our army, have been destroyed without mercy, and the country is almost a desert.
In their flight they seized the farmers wagons had teams for miles around.-- They had not a wagon train in their army, and were forced to this course by their necessities.
The natural result of it was that they made many enemies, and their enemies became Union men. Hundreds of their men who belong in Kentucky and Tennessee deserted and returned home.
Many of them have passed through here, and been provided with passes.

Money matters are at a stand-point here.--Confederate notes sell for twenty-five cents on the dollar, and gold cannot be bought with Tennessee money at less than forty per cent discount.
A dollar of Confederate money will buy about 10 cents in specie.
The people take the United States Treasury notes without hesitation, and are glad to get them in exchange for Tennessee money.
The very appearance of the money, in contrast to the Confederate scrip, is so much in its favor, that people imbibe a liking for it at first sight.
The fine paper and beautiful engraving have gone far towards displacing the botch work of the Richmond machines.
There are persons here who will lose large sums by the sudden decline.
One wealthy citizen had $17,000 of it on hand.
Others had smaller sums, on which they lost invariably seventy-five per cent.

The banks are accountable for it all, having paid it out over their counters, using no other currency, even where depositors had given them good money.
The result is a general prostration of business facilities.
The three banks here partook of the panic, and sent their specie, amounting to several hundred thousand dollars, into the far South.--As soon as they ascertained that they were to be unmolested here, they opened again for business, and found they had put their willing fingers into a trap, from which there is no extrication.
Floyd never let such a chance escape him, and he bagged the specie on the spot.
This leaves the banks with nothing to rely upon as a foundation.

The Bank of Tennessee is considered solvent, but its bills will not buy specie except at an immense discount.
The issue of shinplasters has had the effect to relieve in some measure the want of specie and change, and five-cent notes on the Bank of Tennessee are common, and from that up to fifty cents. Our soldiers gaze with wonder on this currency, but it is the best that is to be had, and they take it in change for United States Treasury notes, getting a hat full in return for at five dollar note.
With money at this low rate of value, goods have been three times as high as in old times, and quite scarce at that.
There are scarcely enough goods in all the city to make up a good stock.

div3.head: For Hire--
div3.p:
A Boy,
accustomed to the dining-room.

For sale — A gen the
Milch Cow.
Apply to

div3.head: For Hire
div3.p:
--For the remainder of the year, a young negro Woman a first-rate house servant, sober, honest, and industrious.
Apply to

div3.head: For Hire
div3.p:
--The balance of the year, a neat and experienced Chambermaid, or Nurse, 14 years old, without encumbrance, who has been accustomed all her life to waiting on young ladies.
To a good home the price will be satisfactory.
Apply to Seabrook's Warehouse, corner of Grace and 17th streets.

div3.head: Ranaway--$20 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway, on the 25th inst., my boy Moses.
He is about 25 years old, 5 feet 10 inches high, of light gingerbread color, with very thick and bushy hair and heavy eyebrows.
He is either in Richmond or lurking about the neighborhood of Mountain road. I will pay $20 to any one who will either bring him to me or put him in the Henrico county jail.

div3.head: $10 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway, on the 8th of March, my man Austin.
He is about 50 years old, 5 feet 8 or 10 inches high; is of a ginger-cake color, has a full head of hair, and walks lame, one leg being shorter than the other, caused by white swelling when he was young.
He has relations in the upper end of Powhatan or Cumberland, where I expect he has gone; or else he may be about Richmond.
Austin is a good shoemaker, and may perhaps pass himself off as a free negro.
I will give the above reward to any one who will bring him to me, or secure him in jail so I get him.
div3.closer:
S. S. Goode.
Skinquarter, Chesterfield. mh 26--3t*

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward
div3.p:
--Will be paid for the arrest and delivery to me of my negro man Arram, if taken outside the city or county, and $25 if within.
He will doubtless try to go to Fredericksburg on the railroad track.
He is 29 years old; black; heavy build; 5 feet 8 or 10 inches high; had on light-colored full cloth clothes; heavy brogans.
Be was brought from King George county, Va., on Monday last.

div3.head: Runaway--$25 reward.
div3.p:
--Left without provocation, about the 1st January last, my boy Henry, about 26 years of age, a barber by trade, hired for the present year to Woermer & Co., opposite the American Hotel.
Henry is a spare, brown colored boy, about 5½ feet high genteel address, wears a small beard, with full head of hair.
He may have hired himself to go with some officer or soldier.
The above reward will be paid for his delivery to me or Mr. Woermer, or any information of his whereabouts, so that I get him.

div3.head: For Rent — House
div3.p:
--For the balance of the year, over Geo. Ruskell's Trimming Store, 91½ Main street--House and Furniture, and everything requisite for keeping house.
The house has two parlors, three rooms above and two garret rooms; good dining-room, kitchen, and servants' room; gas all through the house.
Possession given 1st April.
Apply as above.
